biased_opinion.summary: Rad Dirt Fest is Colorado Rockies adventureâ€”100 km, 2,500 m elevation. Founded ~2018. 80% gravel, 20% dirt. High altitude (2,200-3,000 m), technical climbs. 500-800 riders. Salida, CO (great town). September autumn conditions (10-25Â°C). Affordable entry ($150-$200). If you want Colorado Rockies high-altitude gravel with stunning scenery, this is it. If you need sea-level race, skip it. Altitude is the challenge.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Rad Dirt Fest is Colorado Rockies high-altitude gravel. 100 km, 2,500 m, 2,200-3,000 m altitude. If you want Colorado Rockies scenery with technical climbs, this is it. If you need sea-level, skip it. Altitude is the challenge. Salida is great town. Affordable entry.

history.origin_story: Rad Dirt Fest founded ~2018. Salida, CO. 100 km, 500-800 riders. Colorado Rockies. High altitude gravel.
history.reputation: Colorado gravel scene. Salida. High altitude. Technical climbs. Well-organized.

prestige.explanation: Life Time owns this race, which means corporate polish but zero grassroots soul. Keegan Swenson showed up once in 2024 and won by 83 seconds over Stetina, but it's still fighting for relevance against UNBOUND. The Grand Prix inclusion gives it credibility, but getting dropped from 2025 then added back for 2026 screams second-tier status.

race_quality.explanation: 90% maintained gravel roads that riders call 'champagne gravel' and 'buttery smooth' - this isn't your typical Colorado washboard nightmare. Aid stations every 20-30 miles with proper cutoff times, though that 31-mile no-service stretch will expose the unprepared. Life Time's event machine delivers professional execution, even if it lacks character.

experience.explanation: Spanish Peaks backdrop at 9,000 feet with views that make the suffering worthwhile - 'every grueling climb rewarded with mesmerizing views' as one rider put it. The transition from high desert to aspen forests delivers Colorado beauty without the Leadville death march. Trinidad's old west character adds authenticity that most corporate events lack.

community.explanation: Gravel community shows up hard here - riders consistently praise it as 'incredible and accepting' with particular support for women racers described as 'absolute beasts.' 1,000+ cyclists from 40 states and 11 countries proves drawing power. The welcoming atmosphere builds confidence rather than crushes souls, which is rarer than you'd think.

field_depth.explanation: Swenson, Stetina, Vermeulen, and De Crescenzo's three straight wins show decent elite participation, but it's not UNBOUND depth. Life Time's Grand Prix connection brings quality riders, but the field thins quickly after the top 10. It's a stepping stone race for many, not a destination event for the deepest talent. Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three.

value.explanation: 50 UNBOUND qualifier coins split between 70 and 110-mile distances gives you two shots at the golden ticket. Three distance options mean you're not locked into one suffer-fest, and that 'buttery smooth' gravel delivers performance without destroying equipment. Life Time's production value exceeds most regional events at comparable pricing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $150-$200. Trinidad isn't Aspen pricing, but it's not free either - you'll need lodging since this isn't a day trip for most. Life Time registration fees match their corporate overhead, and getting to southern Colorado requires commitment. The Spanish Peaks Inn crew access point suggests decent accommodation options, but budget accordingly. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

length.explanation: 62 miles hits the sweet spot between 'why bother' and 'please make it stop' - it's the Anteloop distance that bridges desert terrain with snowcapped mountain views. Not long enough to be epic, not short enough to be easy. Perfect for building confidence before attempting the 110-mile Stubborn Delores masochism. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Lauren De Crescenzo puts it: "I tried to go a few times on the steep pitches of the first climb and was finally able to break free on a steep, sandy portion somewhere between miles 25 and 30."

technicality.explanation: That 2-mile South Shore Trail technical section and Burro Canyon's 9-mile climb will test handling skills despite the 'champagne gravel' reputation. 90% maintained roads mean consistent surfaces, but elevation changes and two-track sections demand real bike handling. Not Leadville technical, but far from a rail-trail cruise. More technical than most â€” comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Lauren De Crescenzo puts it: "I tried to go a few times on the steep pitches of the first climb and was finally able to break free on a steep, sandy portion somewhere between miles 25 and 30."

elevation.explanation: 8,202 feet of climbing from 6,025 feet starting elevation to nearly 9,000 at the top - this isn't flat Colorado plains riding. The gradual nature means sustainable power over grinding climbs, but that altitude will find your weak spots. Views of Fisher's Peak and Spanish Peaks justify the leg-burning ascents. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Lauren De Crescenzo puts it: "I tried to go a few times on the steep pitches of the first climb and was finally able to break free on a steep, sandy portion somewhere between miles 25 and 30."

climate.explanation: Late September offers 73-80Â°F highs with 51Â°F lows, but that high desert environment creates hydration challenges - expect 'chapped lips, dry throat, empty bottles.' 72% sunshine sounds nice until you're exposed for hours. Wind averages 14.7 mph, which becomes a factor on those open mesas. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL. As Hannah puts it: "Even though the weather was looking questionable, I was able to finish my first 100 mile ride and beat the rain. Trinidad gravel lived up to all the hype and my legs felt strong throughout the ride."

altitude.explanation: Starting at 6,025 feet and climbing to 9,000 feet means sea-level riders will feel it immediately. That thin air compounds the 8,200+ feet of elevation gain into suffering. Trinidad's elevation isn't Leadville brutal, but it's enough to separate the adapted from the foolish. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

logistics.explanation: Life Time's corporate machine delivers professional organization, but that 31-mile stretch with no cell service between aid stations creates anxiety for many riders. Three crew access points help, but Trinidad's remote location means limited backup options. Spanish Peaks Inn checkpoint at mile 42.8 provides key support, assuming you make the 1:20 PM cutoff.

adventure.explanation: 4,775 square miles of Las Animas County gravel roads deliver exploration through Colorado's largest county. Old railroad ruins, dilapidated mining history, and transition from high desert to alpine forests create real discovery. That no-service 31-mile section forces self-reliance that most corporate events avoid.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Rad serves up champagne gravel and Spanish Peaks views, but that 31-mile no-service stretch will expose every training shortcut you took.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you can hold steady watts for five hours at altitude without external validation, this is your race. The gravel is buttery smooth, but 8,900 feet doesn't negotiate with your sea-level fitness. Show up undertrained and that remote backcountry section becomes a very expensive therapy session.
final_verdict.alternatives: BWR California gives you similar smooth surfaces without the altitude punishment, while Gravel Worlds in Nebraska delivers comparable distances on flatter terrain. Both let you suffer closer to civilization.

videos.title: 2024 Life Time The Rad Dirt Fest | RACE HIGHLIGHTS
videos.description:
Watch the extended highlights of the 2024 Life Time The Rad Dirt Fest, stop #5 of the Life Time Grand Prix presented by Mazda. Set in the rugged and stunning landscapes of Trinidad, Colorado, this scenic gravel race challenges athletes with grueling climbs, technical two track sections, and fast paced descents. Returning champions Alexey Vermeulen and Lauren De Crescenzo seek to defend their titles while LTGP leaders Keegan Swenson, Sofia Gomez VillafaÃ±e are on a quest to lock up the overall. Other race favorites like Pete Stetina, Griffin Easter, Cecily Decker, and Alexis Skarda will also challenge for the coveted RAD guitar that goes home with the winner. Alongside them, over a thousand amateur riders take on the 110, 70, and 40-mile courses, pushing their limits in one of the most unique and funky events of the season.

Learn more about the Life Time Grand Prix: https://www.lifetimegrandprix.com

Learn more about the Rad Dirt Fest: https://www.theraddirt.com

videos.title: New Colorado Summer of Gravel series highlights the state's diverse topography
videos.description:
Colorado has an abundance of gravel race riches this season, including a new series of four great races called the Colorado Summer of Gravel. This new series runs mid-May through July and includes CO2UT in the desert of western Colorado, Telluride Gravel Race in the mountainous south, Ned Gravel high up in central Colorado, and FoCo Fondo to the north in Fort Collins. 

Combined, itâ€™s quite the diverse tour of Coloradoâ€™s varied topography. 

Check out the details:
www.coloradosummerofgravel.com/

quotes.text: The rad belongs to Trinidad and every time I'm out here it's so cool man I love this race I love this community it's going to be a great day on the bike.

This race is like the rat where it's not just a fitness contest it's a bit of a chess match - they are rolling into this chicane at about 20 mph and after 113 miles of racing the only thing standing in the way of the finish line is that last left hand turn on to Main Street.

The road started to get a bit rougher at the same time it started raining so you can see it's starting to stick a little more to the tire - it's getting sticky, getting slick, getting to be more clay.

key_challenges.name: 20% grade opening climb
key_challenges.description: Race starts with a big punchy climb that's 20 plus percent grade. Sets up visibility for the peloton and creates early selection.

key_challenges.name: Final left turn onto Main Street
key_challenges.description: After 113 miles of racing, the only thing standing between riders and the finish line is the last left hand turn onto Main Street.

key_challenges.name: Highway section with no shoulder
key_challenges.description: Rough stretch of highway with 65 mph traffic and no shoulder for a section that riders found unenjoyable and potentially dangerous.

key_challenges.name: Deep rock gravel section
key_challenges.description: Miles of deep rock gravel surface that riders describe as not awesome to ride on.

terrain_notes.text: Road surfaces get rougher and stickier when wet, turning more clay-like. Deep rock gravel sections are challenging to ride on for extended miles.
Mix of flat plains riding with long views followed by climbing into the hills toward the Spanish Peaks. Transition from plains to mountains provides varied terrain.

race_day_tips.text: Weather can change quickly with storms developing. Rain makes clay-like road surfaces sticky and slick, affecting bike handling.
The race has chess match elements beyond just fitness - riders play tactical games, especially at the bottom of climbs after long distances.

additional_quotes.text: Trinidad has done a really nice job of putting together some gravel cycling tourism with curated routes, so when I headed into town I could just pick from a few without having to build something from scratch.

The rad belongs to Trinidad and the community stakeholders, leadership and local businesses become our partners. They show up to volunteer for us and without their partnership this event can't take place.

rider_intel.search_text: Rad Dirt Fest in Trinidad, Colorado features challenging terrain that transitions from flat plains to mountainous climbing toward the Spanish Peaks. The race starts with a punchy 20+ percent grade climb that creates early selection and visibility for the field. After 113 miles of racing, riders face a final left turn onto Main Street to reach the finish. The course includes difficult sections of deep rock gravel that riders find challenging to ride on for extended distances. Weather can be a factor with sudden storms making clay-like road surfaces sticky and slick. One particularly tough section involves highway riding with 65 mph traffic and no shoulder. The race has tactical elements beyond pure fitness, with riders playing chess match games especially at the bottom of climbs. Trinidad has developed gravel cycling tourism with curated routes for visitors. The community strongly supports the event with local businesses and volunteers partnering to make the race possible.
